citations.narrative:
On July 26, 2023, an almost 3-month-old male rhesus macaque was found loose inside one of the indoor animal housing
rooms having sustained a fracture to his right arm. The arm was surgically amputated under anesthesia, just above the
elbow, to facilitate a rapid recovery and return to the dam as well as the social group. The facility’s internal investigation
concluded that the infant got out of the cage through a square hole, approximately 3 inches long by 3 inches wide, a
standard caging feature used to access food from the attached feeding bin at the front of the cage. This enclosure did not
properly contain the infant allowing for the subsequent escape and injury. Housing facilities for non-human primates must
be designed to contain the animals securely and protect them from injury. At the time of inspection, corrective actions and
preventative measures had been implemented.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
Lisa Ekman, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.75(a)  Critical Repeat
   
Housing facilities, general. 
On July 26, 2023, an almost 3-month-old male rhesus macaque was found loose inside one of the indoor animal housing 
rooms having sustained a fracture to his right arm. The arm was surgically amputated under anesthesia, just above the 
elbow, to facilitate a rapid recovery and return to the dam as well as the social group. The facility’s internal investigation 
concluded that the infant got out of the cage through a square hole, approximately 3 inches long by 3 inches wide, a 
standard caging feature used to access food from the attached feeding bin at the front of the cage. This enclosure did not 
properly contain the infant allowing for the subsequent escape and injury. Housing facilities for non-human primates must 
be designed to contain the animals securely and protect them from injury. At the time of inspection, corrective actions and 
preventative measures had been implemented. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Lisa Ekman, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
